title: 112_s599
content: The Act is titled the "Civil War Sesquicentennial Commission Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission Act establishes a commission to ensure a national observance of the Civil War sesquicentennial, explore its causes, and reflect on its consequences as directed by Congress in 1999. The Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission Act establishes a commission to ensure a national observance of the Civil War sesquicentennial, explore its causes, reflect on its consequences, and assist in inclusive observances. It includes consequences such as the Reconstruction era, economic devastation of the South, constricted equal rights for African-Americans, and eventual economic recovery and civil rights extension. The Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission Act aims to recognize all perspectives on the Civil War and support educational and preservation programs. The Civil War Sesquicentennial Commemoration Commission, established by the Secretary of the Interior, is referred to as the "Commission." It aims to recognize all perspectives on the Civil War and support educational and preservation programs. The Commission, composed of 25 members, includes government representatives appointed by Senate and House leaders, Secretaries of Interior, Smithsonian Institution, and Education. The Commission also includes private members appointed by the President from the corporate and nonprofit community. Private members appointed by the President from the corporate and nonprofit community, including experts on Antebellum, Civil War, and Reconstruction eras. The Commission consists of government representatives appointed by Senate and House leaders, Secretaries of Interior, Smithsonian Institution, and Education, as well as private members appointed by the President from the corporate and nonprofit community. The Commission also includes individuals with expertise in art history, historic preservation, anthropology, cultural geography, sociology, political science, law, and economics. Additionally, there is 1 individual with expertise in the preservation of Civil War historic sites and battlefields, and 3 individuals representing State Civil War sesquicentennial efforts. The Commission consists of government and private members appointed by various entities. Government members can continue as Commission members for 30 days after leaving office, while private members serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Initial appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The Commission consists of government and private members appointed by various entities. Government members can continue for 30 days after leaving office, while private members serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Initial appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission shall hold meetings at the call of the chairperson, with a majority of voting members constituting a quorum. The Commission must elect a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson at the initial meeting, and decisions require an affirmative vote of a majority of voting members. Nonvoting members do not participate in voting. The Commission appoints nonvoting members who serve in an advisory capacity. The Commission appoints nonvoting members who serve in an advisory capacity. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with planning and carrying out programs to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, encouraging interdisciplinary examination of the war, promoting Civil War-related activities nationwide, and urging various organizations to participate in activities that enhance understanding of the war's significance. The Commission coordinates the distribution of scholarly research on the Civil War through various institutions and provides technical assistance to states and organizations for the sesquicentennial commemoration activities. The Commission coordinates and facilitates commemoration activities of Federal agencies related to the sesquicentennial of the Civil War. They develop programs and facilities to ensure a positive legacy and long-term public benefit. Additionally, they encourage the preservation of Civil War-related historic sites and battlefields as a lasting legacy. The Commission also plans and carries out programs and activities using funds raised from individuals, foundations, and corporations for national sesquicentennial activities. They may provide funds to State and local programs that advance the goals of the Commission. The Commission prepares strategic plans and annual reports for its activities, including listing gifts over $250 and their donors. They also encourage international involvement in Civil War commemoration activities. The Commission shall submit a final report to Congress by December 30, 2015, including a summary of activities, accounting of funds, and findings/recommendations. The National Endowment for the Humanities will award grants for activities related to the sesquicentennial of the Civil War, giving priority to programs focusing on the role of African Americans. The Commission has powers outlined in section 8. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, appoint advisory committees, authorize actions by members or employees, procure supplies, and use the United States mails. The Commission can use the United States mails and establish an independent foundation affiliated with the Commission to support its efforts. SEC. 9. PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission and advisory committee members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director, whose employment must be confirmed by the Commission. The Chairperson can set the compensation for the executive director and other personnel, with a maximum pay rate specified. The Commission can request Federal agencies to detail personnel to assist without interruption of civil service status. They can also accept voluntary services and the National Park Service will provide support services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may request administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at specified rates. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. The Inspector General of the Department of the Interior will conduct an annual audit of the Commission, with results made public. Authorization of appropriations includes $500,000 for fiscal years 2012-2016 for Act implementation, and $3,500,000 for grants under section 7 to the National Endowment for the Humanities.
